abstract: This article argues that different narratives involving sacrifice compete to ascribe meaning to the 11 September 1973 coup against Socialist President Salvador Allende, and as a result, structure contemporary Chilean constitutional politics. From that event, it is contended, three competing narratives emerged, each seeking to make sense of political sacrifice, and each providing a basis for the constitutional projects of the Left, the Right, and the Center.
title: Competing Narratives about Sacrifice: Three Readings of the September 11, 1973 Coup in Chile and their Conflicting Constitutional Projections
subject: law
